newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan central bank leaves money policy unchanged.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan central bank leaves money policy unchanged.

text.p: Taiwan's central bank board agreed in a meeting on Thursday to leave its monetary policy unchanged, pledging to maintain a stable-to-loose policy, central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong said.
"We will maintain our stable-to-loose monetary policy," Sheu told reporters after a meeting of the bank's board.
"If liquidity remains loose we will conduct open market operations," Sheu said.

The central bank has maintained a similar monetary policy for weeks, trying to strike a balance that keeps interest rates low enough to stimulate the flagging economy without undermining the interests of bank depositors.
Sheu encouraged other government departments to work with the central bank in a concerted effort to stimulate investment, saying the bank could not do this alone.
"The current slow economy is not something that can be solved solely by central bank monetary policy," Sheu said. "We need the cooperation of other agencies in order to boost investment incentive."

Sheu and other bank officials said repeatedly in October, including after an October 19 board meeting, that liquidity in the banking system had become "slightly too loose" but that the bank would maintain an "appropriately loose" monetary policy.
This meant preventing interest rates from dropping too low so as not to hurt the interests of most depositors, officials have said, cautioning that monetary policy was no cure-all for the economy.

Five consecutive reductions in commercial banks' reserve requirements between mid-1995 and August 1996 had made money more accessible but failed to ignite investment, central bank officials have said.
